content: Branch: change course to focus on remote-friendly sessions and async collaboration.

Wonderful—let’s adopt a remote-friendly, async workflow. Here are practical ways we can work together without needing real-time chat:

Async collaboration options (choose one or mix them)
- Option 1: You share the exact YouTube link and the timestamp where the bird appears. I’ll identify the species and return a structured note you can save in a shared document.
- Option 2: You provide a detailed description of the moment (colors, size, beak shape, distinctive markings, what the bird is doing, and approximate location in the scene). I’ll identify the species and explain the reasoning.
- Option 3: You paste the video description or captions (the list of clips and animals). I’ll pinpoint the bird species from those descriptions.
- Option 4: I fetch the BBC Earth page myself and pull details from the description/captions. If you’d like, I can start by searching for the clip page once you give me the clip title or a link.

Suggested output format (so you can drop it into a shared doc)
- Clip: BBC Earth – Top 5 Silliest Animal Moments
- Link: [URL]
- Timestamp: [00:xx]
- Bird species: [Name] (Confidence: [x%])
- Key identifying features: [colors, size, beak shape, crest/markings]
- What the bird did: [action in the clip]
- Scene/location hints: [water/trees/ground, etc.]
- Why this species fits: [brief reasoning]
- Alternative candidates: [list any close possibilities]
- Sources/caption references: [link or timestamp to the description]

Practical notes for async work
- I can wait for your input and respond with a complete note as soon as you share the materials.
- I can store the results in a shared document or note with a running log of clips, so you can review later.
- If you want, I can also draft a lightweight template (Google Doc or Notion page) you can reuse for future clips.

Which option would you like to start with? If you’d like, I can kick off with Option 4 right away by searching for the BBC Earth clip page once you provide the clip title or a link.

Nice plan. I recommend starting with Option 4 (fetch the BBC Earth clip page and pull details from the description/captions). Here’s how we can proceed and what I’ll deliver.

What I need from you
- Clip title or a direct link to the BBC Earth page (or
- If you don’t have a link, I can search for the clip by title once you give me the title).

If you’d prefer not to use BBC Earth, we can switch to Option 2 (detailed moment description) right away.

Suggested output format (ready to drop into a shared doc)
- Clip: BBC Earth – [Clip Title]
- Link: [URL]
- Timestamp: [00:xx]
- Bird species: [Name] (Confidence: [x%])
- Key identifying features: [colors, size, beak shape, crest/markings]
- What the bird did: [action in the clip]
- Scene/location hints: [water/trees/ground, etc.]
- Why this species fits: [brief reasoning]
- Alternative candidates: [list any close possibilities]
- Sources/caption references: [link or timestamp to the description]

Optional: I can also create a lightweight template in your preferred tool (Google Docs or Notion) and store a running log for multiple clips.

Would you like me to start with Option 4 now? If yes, share the clip title or link (or tell me to search for it), and I’ll fetch the page and draft the first note.
